channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Science background, or a passing interest in life sciences? Junior/mid-level Perl developer needed in London...
item.description: Friendly and quiet office in London (W1) looking for a Perl (or similar) developer with at least two years experience. Youâ€™re expected to have fullstack experience/abilities, from improvements on the clientâ€™s HTML front-end to backend services. Itâ€™s a small company, so thereâ€™s some fluidility expected between roles - a good place to expand on your jack-of-all-software-trades skillset.

item.title: Perhaps the most enlightened Perl team in London
item.description: Itâ€™s no secret that I used to run a Perl team myself in Central London, and was competing for talent with the other teams. By far the hardest team to compete with was the one whose technical leader was making sure his team were always using the best tools, was always taking a personal interest in his teamâ€™s technical output â€” adding his considerable technical knowledge and experience to the team, and was always talking about these things at various London Perl events.

item.title: Perl for High Performance; Senior Developer, West London
item.description: Do you know how to solve problems in terms of queues and caches? Does the idea of truly scaling your architecture on AWS excite you? Not fazed by designing your workloads to be distributed?

item.title: Core Perl OOP: Constructor arguments
Alan Kayâ€™s critique of the TPF grants program
item.description: Aristotle quotes Alan Kay, suggesting that we should consider focussing on funding people who do good things for Perl, rather than worrying so much on specific projects.

item.title: The blogs.perl.org update grant has been cancelled
item.description: In 2015 a grant was awarded to switch blogs.perl.org to a new blog engine. The grant has stalled, and so the grants committee has decided to cancel the grant. They would still welcome someone replacing the current engine behind blogs.perl.org.

item.title: Grant extension request by Tony Cook
item.description: Tony Cook has asked for an extension to his Perl 5 maintenance grant: $20k for another 400 hours of work.

item.title: Collisions in Block Names in Jemplate
item.description: E Choroba got Jemplate in the pull request challenge, and in fixing a bug in that, he ended up fixing the same bug in the Template Toolkit (Jemplate is an implementation of the Template Toolkit in Javascript).

item.title: The Perl Conference USA 2017
item.description: The organisers of The Perl Conference (YAPC::NA as was) have started sharing parts of the schedule, and encourage interested parties to sign up now!

item.title: Specifying the type of your CPAN dependencies
item.description: The third article in a series about the distribution metadata that you'll find in the META.json file. This article was supported by MaxMind, a gold sponsor for the summit.

item.title: The Perl Toolchain Summit Project List
item.description: Before the Toolchain Summit starts, the attendees are asked to add their work list to the wiki. Everyone is invited to have a look at the project list, and let us know if there are additional things you want to suggest for inclusion (bug fixes, new features, etc).

item.title: The root of all eval
item.description: Carl ruminates on Perl 6's EVAL built-in, which is a bit different from Perl 5's eval.

item.title: Perl 6 IO TPF Grant: Monthly Report (April, 2017)
item.description: An update on Zoffix's work on Perl 6 IO.

item.title: Massively reducing MoarVM Fixed Size Allocator contention
item.description: Jonathan has made significant improvements to how MoarVM handles memory allocation in multithreaded applications.

item.title: Trials and troubles with changing @INC
item.description: Up to now, the @INC variable (used to search for modules when your program uses them), has had '.' (the current directory) in it. But this is a security risk, so in Perl 5.26 @INC will no longer contain '.'. Ryan goes through what that might mean for your CPAN distributions, and has assembled a list of distributions that appear to break with this change. If you're an author, check for your distribution(s) please!

item.title: P5P Mailing List Summary: April 11th-16th
item.description: Sawyer's weekly update from the P5P mailing list.

item.title: Autoload::AUTOCAN - Autoloading the easy way
item.description: Dand introduces his Autoload::AUTOCAN module, which makes it easier to do Autoload right.

item.title: Creating a pivot table from an SQL query
item.description: Max introduces his new module, DBIx::PivotQuery, which lets you build pivot tables, similar to those you can use in Excel.

item.title: Alternatives to rand()
item.description: Dana reviewed CPAN modules you can use for random number generation, in place of the rand built-in.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: #300 - 300th issue of Perl Weekly
item.description:
This is the 300th issue of Perl Weekly! Nearly six years ago, Gabor put out issue number 1, and hasn't missed a week since. Various editors have come, and gone, and returned, but Gabor is still the driving force behind it. Thank you, Gabor.

If you're a CPAN author, please have a read of Ryan's article about one of the changes coming soon in Perl 5.26.0.

Neil
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
